newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end up on short-covering.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end up on short-covering.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended mostly up on Tuesday on short-covering, traders said.
The most active July 1997 contract ended at 24,050 yuan ($2,899) per tonne, rising 90 yuan. It opened at 24,010 yuan, hitting an intraday low of 24,000 and a high of 24,130.
April fell 10 to 23,500, May rose 90 to 23,690, June 80 to 23,880, August 120 to 24,070, September 170 to 24,070 and October 150 to 23,950.
Combined volume rose to 26,840 tonnes from 10,670.

Copper opened slightly higher and moved at that level for most of the session with some investors continuing to liquidate their short positions due to the unclear short-term market trend, traders said.
"Many investors wanted to stay on the sidelines due to a lack of direction from the London Metal Exchange," one trader said. "Speculative buying dominated today's trading."
Traders said copper would find it hard to move out of the current narrow range around 24,000 yuan in the absence of market-moving news in the short term.
Aluminium ended mixed. April was unchanged at 16,150, May fell 50 to 16,400 and June rose 50 to 16,750.
Combined volume fell to 710 tonnes from 1,480.
